Change of Variables

The Jacobian

...were a group of revolutionaries who presided over the French Revolution's reins during its Reign of Terror from 1795 to 1800.

Just as integrals of the type

∫f(x)f′(x) dx\int f(x) f'(x)\ dx∫f(x)f′(x) dx

can be solved via a substitution u=f(x)u = f(x)u=f(x), du=f′(x)du = f'(x)du=f′(x), can we choose to substitute in a set of two alternate variables (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) in place of (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and derive consequent expressions for dududu and dvdvdv?

The answer is yes - though such expressions are a great deal more complicated than the single-integral case. We claim the following

Theorem. For a change of variables (x,y)→(u,v)(x,y) \to (u,v)(x,y)→(u,v) in which uuu and vvv are continuous and invertible functions of xxx and yyy, an area integral over a region DDD can be written as

∫Dϕ(x,y) dx dy=∫Dϕ(u,v) ∣J(u,v)∣ du dv\int_D \phi(x,y) \ dx \ dy = \int_D \phi(u,v)\ |J(u,v)| \ du \ dv∫D​ϕ(x,y) dx dy=∫D​ϕ(u,v) ∣J(u,v)∣ du dv

where the Jacobian J(u,v)J(u,v)J(u,v) is defined as the matrix determinant

J(u,v)=∣∂x∂u∂x∂v∂y∂u∂y∂v∣=∣xuxvyuyv∣J(u,v) = \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\partial x}{\partial u} & \frac{\partial x}{\partial v} \\ \frac{\partial y}{\partial u} & \frac{\partial y}{\partial v} \end{vmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix} x_u & x_v \\ y_u & y_v \end{vmatrix}J(u,v)=∣∣​∂u∂x​∂u∂y​​∂v∂x​∂v∂y​​∣∣​=∣∣​xu​yu​​xv​yv​​∣∣​

with alternative notation

J(u,v)=∂(x,y)∂(u,v).J(u,v) = \frac{\partial (x,y)}{\partial (u,v)}.J(u,v)=∂(u,v)∂(x,y)​.

Note that we stipulated for uuu and vvv to be invertible; this means that for the transformation u=u(x,y),v=v(x,y)u = u(x,y), v = v(x,y)u=u(x,y),v=v(x,y), we have the corresponding inverse transformation x=f(u,v),y=g(u,v)x = f(u,v), y = g(u,v)x=f(u,v),y=g(u,v).

Proof (insanely non-rigorous).

This proof is sketchier than an eyewitness courtrom sketch of the Zodiac Killer, but we forge ahead regardless. The crux of the transformation from (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) to (u,v)(u,v)(u,v) in the context of an area integral is that the area differential dAdAdA must now be represented not as dx dydx\ dydx dy, but some expression of dududu and dvdvdv; thus, the crucial question is what that expression is.

Let's denote an infinitesimal change in uuu and vvv as δu\delta uδu and δv\delta vδv respectively; at such infinitesimal scales, both can be assumed to be perfectly straight, but not necessarily orthogonal (unlike dxdxdx and dydydy). The small region bounded by δu\delta uδu and δv\delta vδv is thus a parallelogram:

Given that x=f(u,v)x = f(u,v)x=f(u,v) and y=g(u,v)y = g(u,v)y=g(u,v), the question is now how to express the product δxδy\delta x \delta yδxδy in terms of δu\delta uδu and δv\delta vδv. By Taylor's Theorem, we have

δx=f(u+δu,v+δv)−f(u,v)=[f(u,v)+((δu,δv)⋅∇)f(u,v)+...]−f(u,v)=((δu,δv)⋅∇)f(u,v)=(δu,δv)⋅(fu,fv)=(δu)fu+(δv)fv\begin{aligned} \delta x &= f(u + \delta u, v + \delta v) - f(u,v) \\ &= [f(u,v) + ((\delta u, \delta v)\cdot \nabla)f(u,v) + ...] - f(u,v) \\ &= ((\delta u, \delta v)\cdot \nabla)f(u,v) \\ &= (\delta u, \delta v) \cdot (f_u, f_v) \\ &= (\delta u) f_u + (\delta v) f_v \end{aligned}δx​=f(u+δu,v+δv)−f(u,v)=[f(u,v)+((δu,δv)⋅∇)f(u,v)+...]−f(u,v)=((δu,δv)⋅∇)f(u,v)=(δu,δv)⋅(fu​,fv​)=(δu)fu​+(δv)fv​​

where the ......... in the Taylor expansion conceal second-order and higher-order terms which vanish for very small δv\delta vδv and δu\delta uδu, and

δy=g(u+δu,v+δv)−g(u,v)=[g(u,v)+((δu,δv)⋅∇)g(u,v)+...]−g(u,v)=((δu,δv)⋅∇)g(u,v)=(δu,δv)⋅(gu,gv)=(δu)gu+(δv)gv\begin{aligned} \delta y &= g(u + \delta u, v + \delta v) - g(u,v) \\ &= [g(u,v) + ((\delta u, \delta v)\cdot \nabla)g(u,v) + ...] - g(u,v) \\ &= ((\delta u, \delta v)\cdot \nabla)g(u,v) \\ &= (\delta u, \delta v) \cdot (g_u, g_v) \\ &= (\delta u) g_u + (\delta v) g_v \end{aligned}δy​=g(u+δu,v+δv)−g(u,v)=[g(u,v)+((δu,δv)⋅∇)g(u,v)+...]−g(u,v)=((δu,δv)⋅∇)g(u,v)=(δu,δv)⋅(gu​,gv​)=(δu)gu​+(δv)gv​​

or, in matrix form,

[δxδy]=[fufvgugv][δuδv]=J(u,v)[δuδv]\begin{bmatrix} \delta x \\ \delta y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} f_u & f_v \\ g_u & g_v \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \delta u \\ \delta v \end{bmatrix} = J(u,v)\begin{bmatrix} \delta u \\ \delta v \end{bmatrix}[δxδy​]=[fu​gu​​fv​gv​​][δuδv​]=J(u,v)[δuδv​]

thus indicating that the determinant ∣J(u,v)∣|J(u,v)|∣J(u,v)∣ represents the (signed) area of the parallelogram formed by δu\delta uδu and δv\delta vδv.

Polar coordinates in 2D

Trigonometric substitution for single integrals are useful, but for double integrals, they are downright lifesaving. As it turns out, many regions - from circles to half-circles to quarter-circles to... well, mainly just circles, but anything involving angles - are better represented with polar coordinates (r,θ)(r, \theta)(r,θ) than with Cartesian coordinates (x,y)(x,y)(x,y); for instance, the circle x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 is simply represented by r=1r=1r=1 in polar coordinates.

Thus let us define the change of coordinates

{r=x2+y2θ=tan⁡−1(yx)\begin{cases} r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} \\ \theta = \tan^{-1}(\frac{y}{x}) \end{cases}{r=x2+y2​θ=tan−1(xy​)​

or, conversely and more familiarly,

{x=rcos⁡θy=rsin⁡θ.\begin{cases} x = r\cos \theta \\ y = r\sin \theta. \end{cases}{x=rcosθy=rsinθ.​

Using the Jacobian as above gives us a clue into how double integrals expressed in polar coordinates are evaluated. As formulated previously, we have

J(r,θ)=∂(x,y)∂(r,θ)=∣x(r,θ)rx(r,θ)θy(r,θ)ry(r,θ)θ∣=∣cos⁡θ−rsin⁡θsin⁡θrcos⁡θ∣=r!J(r,\theta) = \frac{\partial (x,y)}{\partial (r,\theta)} = \begin{vmatrix} x(r,\theta)_r & x(r,\theta)_\theta \\ y(r,\theta)_r & y(r,\theta)_\theta \end{vmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix} \cos \theta & -r \sin \theta\\ \sin \theta & r\cos\theta \end{vmatrix} = r!J(r,θ)=∂(r,θ)∂(x,y)​=∣∣​x(r,θ)r​y(r,θ)r​​x(r,θ)θ​y(r,θ)θ​​∣∣​=∣∣​cosθsinθ​−rsinθrcosθ​∣∣​=r!

(No factorial intended.)

Thus we simply have

Theorem. Change of coordinates from Cartesian to polar in double integration.

∫Df(x,y) dx dy=∫Df(r,θ) r dr dθ\int_D f(x,y)\ dx\ dy = \int_D f(r,\theta) \ r\ dr\ d\theta∫D​f(x,y) dx dy=∫D​f(r,θ) r dr dθ

which is quite agreeable, as far as mathematical results go.

A further geometric argument may lend much-needed credence to this Jacobian willy-nilly nonsense:

I have never glanced upon such curious symbols in my entire life. Perchance you meant to type in rrr and θ\thetaθ but slipped, sir or madam?

Subdividing a region with respect to polar coordinates results in infinitesimal sectors, which - when small enough - can be treated as sectors of a circle with radius rrr at that point. The arc length of such a sector is r dθr \ d\thetar dθ, in radians; the "rectangle" pictured above thus has area r dr dθr\ dr\ d\thetar dr dθ.

The following example is quite nice. By this point it should be well-known that me and Vector Calculus are mortal enemies and neither of us can live while the other survives, etc., etc., and good opinion from me towards a problem is rarely bestowed and therefore more worth the earning, so you can be assured that this example is very nice indeed:

Example. Find the value of ∫−∞∞e−x2 dx.\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-x^2}\ dx.∫−∞∞​e−x2 dx.

The famed Gaussian integral, at long last! Normally this question would be reserved for a Statistics course, though the expression is so ubiquitous it surely rings a bell; this is one mean integral, not least because it is non-elementary - the antiderivative of e−x2e^{-x^2}e−x2 cannot be described using elementary functions like polynomials, exponentials, trigonometry, and the like.

So what to do? We propose that there is another integral, now a double integral instead of a single integral, that embeds within it our desired value, but is far, far simpler to evaluate:

I=∫Dae−(x2+y2) dx dyI = \int_{D_a} e^{-(x^2+y^2)}\ dx\ dyI=∫Da​​e−(x2+y2) dx dy

where DaD_aDa​ is a circular disk of radius aaa centered about the origin. As a→∞a \to \inftya→∞, the integral will range over all real numbers and the two-dimensional slice of the integrated volume when y=0y=0y=0 will be our desired answer.

But why is this a simplification? Let's think back to polar coordinates - what in particular attracts us to them? Perhaps the fact that x2+y2=r2x^2 + y^2 = r^2x2+y2=r2 lies chief among our clues: under transformation (x,y)→(r,θ)(x,y) \to (r,\theta)(x,y)→(r,θ), we have

I=∫Dae−r2 r dr dθ=∫02π∫0are−r2 dr dθI = \int_{D_a}e^{-r^2}\ r\ dr\ d\theta = \int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_0^a re^{-r^2}\ dr\ d\thetaI=∫Da​​e−r2 r dr dθ=∫02π​∫0a​re−r2 dr dθ

where θ\thetaθ ranges from 000 to 2π2\pi2π for a full circle, and rrr ranges from 000 to aaa to describe that circle. The inner integral can now be solved via substitution, observing that r2r^2r2 differentiates into rrr:

∫0are−r2 dr dθ=−12[e−r2]0a=−12[e−a2−1]\int_0^{a}re^{-r^2}\ dr\ d\theta = -\frac{1}{2}[e^{-r^2}]^{a}_0 = -\frac{1}{2}[e^{-a^2}-1]∫0a​re−r2 dr dθ=−21​[e−r2]0a​=−21​[e−a2−1]

which converges to 12\frac{1}{2}21​ as a→∞a\to \inftya→∞. Thus we have, miraculously:

lim⁡a→∞I=∫02π12 dθ=π.\lim_{a\to\infty}I = \int_0^{2\pi}\frac{1}{2}\ d\theta = \pi.a→∞lim​I=∫02π​21​ dθ=π.

One last step: how do we get from here, the double integral of e(−x2+y2)e^{(-x^2+y^2)}e(−x2+y2), to where we wanted to go - the single integral of just e−x2e^{-x^2}e−x2? Symmetry. Taking a closer look at III reveals that

I=∫Dae−(x2+y2) dx dy=∫Dae−x2e−y2 dx dy=∫−∞∞e−y2(∫−∞∞e−x2 dx) dy\begin{aligned} I &= \int_{D_a} e^{-(x^2+y^2)}\ dx\ dy \\ &= \int_{D_a} e^{-x^2} e^{-y^2}\ dx\ dy \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-y^2}(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-x^2}\ dx)\ dy\\ \end{aligned}I​=∫Da​​e−(x2+y2) dx dy=∫Da​​e−x2e−y2 dx dy=∫−∞∞​e−y2(∫−∞∞​e−x2 dx) dy​

as e−y2e^{-y^2}e−y2 can be treated as constant w.r.t. xxx, and thus

I=(∫−∞∞e−x2 dx)(∫−∞∞e−y2 dy)I = (\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-x^2}\ dx)(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-y^2}\ dy)I=(∫−∞∞​e−x2 dx)(∫−∞∞​e−y2 dy)

but the two terms in the above product should be identical because they are the same integral under a different variable, leading to

I=(∫−∞∞e−x2 dx)2=πI = (\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-x^2}\ dx)^2 = \piI=(∫−∞∞​e−x2 dx)2=π

by the above, and finally, that

∫−∞∞e−x2 dx=π\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}e^{-x^2}\ dx = \sqrt{\pi}∫−∞∞​e−x2 dx=π​

taking the positive root as the integrand is positive everywhere in R\mathbb{R}R.

This is a pretty amazing result. I'm hard-pressed to say exactly what's so amazing about it - maybe I could wax poetic about how it near-miraculously connects eee to π\piπ, or maybe it finally reveals the mysterious connection between the normal distribution and the presence of 12π\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}2π​1​, but in cases like this, no words can more eloquently describe the elegance of such results than these: holy fricking shit.
